node.title: John Kerry, U.S. Climate Envoy, Tells Top Polluters ‘We Must All Move Faster’
node.alt: John Kerry, the United States climate envoy, at the COP26 climate change conference in Glasgow in November.
node.description: The United States hosted a virtual meeting of big polluting countries on Thursday as nations struggle to meet their climate change goals.
node.content: ["WASHINGTON \u2014 John Kerry, President Biden\u2019s global climate envoy, warned nations Thursday that the world is \u201cnot on a good track\u201d to meet its goal of pivoting away from fossil fuels in order to avoid the most dangerous consequences of climate change.", "At a virtual meeting of the world\u2019s most polluting countries \u2014 including China, Russia and Saudi Arabia \u2014 Mr. Kerry asked ministers to outline what their governments are doing to cut greenhouse gas emissions and to follow through on promises made at a United Nations climate summit last year in Glasgow.", "The meeting was the first gathering since the Glasgow conference of leaders from major economies as well as small island nations and other countries particularly vulnerable to climate change. Though just over two months have passed since the meeting, Mr. Kerry said change was not happening fast enough.", "\u201cOne thing is clear: We all must move faster in this decade to accelerate the transition from coal to renewables,\u201d Mr. Kerry said in a statement after the closed-door meeting.", "He was more blunt at an event sponsored by the United States Chamber of Commerce this week.", "\u201cWe\u2019re in trouble. I hope everyone can understand that,\u201d Mr. Kerry said. \u201cNot trouble we can\u2019t get out of. But we\u2019re not on a good track.\u201d", "Nations have vowed to keep average global temperatures from rising more than 1.5 degrees Celsius, or 2.7 degrees Fahrenheit, compared to preindustrial levels. That\u2019s the threshold beyond which scientists say the dangers of devastating sea level rise, heat waves, drought and wildfires rises significantly. The world has already warmed an average of 1.1 degrees Celsius.", "Mr. Kerry noted in a statement that the world used 9 percent more coal last year than in 2020, and that nearly 300 gigawatts of new coal power is in the construction pipeline. That comes at a time when the International Energy Agency has said countries must shut down at least 870 gigawatts of coal in the next eight years to have a hope of keeping global temperatures at bay.", "\u201cFar from building new plants, we need to be shutting down existing plants,\u201d Mr. Kerry said.", "Few countries have the policies in place to meet their individual climate goals. The United States has not.", "Mr. Biden promised to cut America\u2019s greenhouse gas emissions up to 52 percent below 2005 levels by the end of this decade. Legislation critical to meeting that goal, however, is stalled in Congress.", "Questions remain about a promise at the heart of the deal in Glasgow: Countries agreed to spend this year developing new climate targets to more aggressively cut their emissions.", "But there are discouraging signs. Mr. Kerry has said the United States is not expected to put forward new goals. So has Australia, even though it is considered a climate laggard.", "On Thursday Steven Guilbeault, the Canadian environment minister, said his country would not submit a new target. Mr. Guilbeault said that Canada had increased its ambition ahead of the Glasgow summit, pledging to cut emissions 40 to 45 percent below 2005 levels this decade.", "\u201cI\u2019m not saying it doesn\u2019t apply to us and we\u2019re shutting the door to the possibility of further increasing our targets,\u201d Mr. Guilbeault said. But the government is focusing on meeting goals it has already set, he said.", "President Xi Jinping of China this week suggested that he would not reduce emissions at the expense of other priorities like food and energy security \u201cto ensure the normal life of the masses.\u201d China is the world\u2019s largest greenhouse gas emitter.", "At Thursday\u2019s meeting, countries discussed working together to cut methane, a powerful greenhouse gas that seeps into the atmosphere from oil and gas wells, and set collective goals regarding electric vehicles and green energy from wind, solar or other sources."]
